title: Shayher Group buys Brisbane Q&A Centre for $395m
text:
“Our divestment of Q &A Centre represents the successful execution of QIC Global Real Estate’s investor-endorsed strategy for the QIC Property Fund,” Michael O’Brien, managing director of QIC Global Real Estate, said.

“This transaction follows the sale of Noosa Civic Shopping Centre in Queensland last month, as well as the highly successful sales of 80 Collins Street in Melbourne in May 2019, and MLC Centre in Sydney in 2017, with Q &A Centre the last predominantly office asset remaining in the fund,” he said.

Colliers International’s Jason Lynch, Lachlan MacGillivray and Don McKenzie and JLL’s Seb Turnbull, Jacob Swan and Luke Billiau brokered the deal.

Significant interest

Mr Lynch said the sales campaign generated significant interest from domestic and offshore investors.

"On a global basis, Australia, particularly Brisbane, is attractive on a comparative return basis. Investors were attracted to the strong and diverse mix of covenants underpinned by the Commonwealth of Australia as the major tenant occupying the entirety of the 140 Elizabeth Street office tower," he said.

Mr Turnbull said positive growth in effective office rents, moderate supply and increased demand from small occupiers was attracting capital to Brisbane as an alternative to the Sydney and Melbourne office markets.

"Brisbane has a compelling value proposition with an average 81 basis point yield discount to Sydney and Melbourne," he said.

Advertisement

Shayher Group has been very active in the Brisbane market.

The property group is behind one of the city's biggest projects, Brisbane Quarter, a $1 billion mixed-use precinct under construction with three towers being developed on Brisbane's former Supreme Court site.

In August, it bought one of Brisbane's big inner city development sites, a 20-hectare riverside property known as Bulimba Barracks, which was sold by the federal government's Department of Defence after 18 months on the market.

In Melbourne, their $1 billion retail and residential project is under way, which will transform the heritage-listed Pentridge Prison.
description: The Taiwanese developer has bought the Q&A Centre in Brisbane's CBD on a yield of 6.25 per cent.
